excerpts: I used to pass by here after work years ago and grab the Korean Steak Sandwich for lunch.
It was $8 back then.
I left the Bay Area for a few years and came back to discover that the Korean sandwich is $13.
Bummer
The Korean steak was hot, not too salty, and had enough ginger and soy.
Garlic aioli was creamy and actually had garlic flavor.
Acidity from the pickled onions helped cut through the richness of everything.
There was enough cheddar and it melted just enough to act as sandwich glue.
The entire sandwich was juicy, yet, had great structural integrity and didn't fall apart in my hand.
Nothing in this sandwich was an afterthought.
The Korean steak was hot, not too salty, and had enough ginger and soy.

There was enough cheddar and it melted just enough to act as sandwich glue.

korean steak.author: John B.
korean steak.review:
Pass by Rhea's if you want to see what good sandwich is supposed to look like! 

What Changed: The price soared in the past few years! But I guess that's just SOP. I used to pass by here after work years ago and grab the Korean Steak Sandwich for lunch. It was $8 back then. I left the Bay Area for a few years and came back to discover that the Korean sandwich is $13. Bummer but I'll still pay that price. 

What Didn't: This unassuming liquor store still makes some of the best sandwiches around! I was initially a bit worried that my high rating was somehow due to nostalgia, however, my recent return to Rhea's reminded me of why they deserve five stars. The ACME sweet roll was perfect for this application. I feel that bread is too often under appreciated in a sandwich and merely thought of as a vehicle to hold the fillings together. But here, that sweet roll had a nice crust, chewy texture, a kinda open crumb so there were enough air pockets that the aioli/hot sauce can fill with flavor, and the bread alone had good flavor as well. You know when you have a subpar sandwich that uses inferior bread? You reach the last bite where it's just the bread left and you're kinda like "no thanks I'm good." Yeah. That doesn't happen at Rhea's. The Korean steak was hot, not too salty, and had enough ginger and soy. Garlic aioli was creamy and actually had garlic flavor. Acidity from the pickled onions helped cut through the richness of everything. There was enough cheddar and it melted just enough to act as sandwich glue. The entire sandwich was juicy, yet, had great structural integrity and didn't fall apart in my hand. Nothing in this sandwich was an afterthought. Nothing! 

Extra Info: 
-Their hot sauce is not actually that spicy. And that's fine. I'd like to enjoy all the other flavors in my sandwich rather than feel too much of a kick in this situation. Order the spicy if you want to actually feel any heat. If not, go with mild or medium. Doesn't matter which. They are practically the same. 
-Barely any seating inside. Instead, purchase some chips and a drink and walk over to Dolores Park to eat with a fantastic view of the city!

excerpts: The Korean steak sandwich is my all-time favorite
korean steak.author: Jeff P.
korean steak.review:
Love Rhea's Deli for their amazingly delicious sandwiches.  I have never been disappointed and have always enjoyed every single bite!    The Korean steak sandwich is my all-time favorite and I tend to order it 90% of the time but every other sandwich I have tried is superb!

I always call ahead because they can get super busy--it a good 10-15 minute drive for me across town into the beautiful Mission district 
and parking is of course consistency a challenge but it is worth it!

I Love Rhea's!

Indeed a super pleasant and delicious surprise every time!!!

excerpts: With that, I ordered their well known Korean steak sandwich for $12-ish.
korean steak.author: Mandi W.
korean steak.review:
I don't like sandwiches. There I said it.

With that, I ordered their well known Korean steak sandwich for $12-ish. 

It was so good I was really frustrated I had to share it with my boyfriend. Like, I considered taking it back. My sister also got a sandwich... When she set hers down I also considered taking hers for myself as well.

Get your own sandwich. You're welcome.

excerpts: I got the Korean Steak, mild.
The meat was tender and flavorful.
The mild was the perfect level of spicy for me.
One of the best sandwiches I've eaten EVER, and it was super filling.
If you're a smaller eater like me, you can even split the sandwich and be full.
korean steak.author: Danielle T.
korean steak.review:
I don't like sandwiches AT ALL, but I LOVED the sandwich I got at Rhea's. I got the Korean Steak, mild. The meat was tender and flavorful. The mild was the perfect level of spicy for me. One of the best sandwiches I've eaten EVER, and it was super filling. If you're a smaller eater like me, you can even split the sandwich and be full. Rhea's may be changing my mind about sandwiches! 

Rhea's also has a large variety of drinks and chips to accompany your sandwich. We tried out the Kettle brand Korean BBQ chips. It didn't taste much like Korean BBQ; it just tasted like regular barbecue chips. 

Take your sandwich to Mission Delores Park located only a couple blocks away, and it's a perfect picnic lunch!

excerpts: So far, I've tried the korean steak, the panda and the miss piggy.
My favorite is the miss piggy because it comes with pesto sauce, mozerella, and it has really good flavoring.
I ordered it based on yelp reviews and they didn't have it on the menu, but they knew what it was when I asked.
I didn't know this was a vegetarian sandwich
and I really should've double checked.
Next time I'll be ordering this, but with dutch crunch & salami or some type of meat!
BUT the sandwich itself was really good even without the meat, so
I'd say try the miss piggy with meat & dutch crunch, if you love pesto like I do!
I'm definitely coming back to re-do my order next time.
korean steak.author: Melanie T.
korean steak.review:
Their prices have raised a bit and it's pretty similar to Ike's sandwiches now. When you enter, they have little forms on the table for you to fill out for your sandwich. 

So far, I've tried the korean steak, the panda and the miss piggy. We wanted to order the chicken katsu today, but the worker said they don't serve it at this location anymore.

My favorite is the miss piggy because it comes with pesto sauce, mozerella, and it has really good flavoring. I ordered it based on yelp reviews and they didn't have it on the menu, but they knew what it was when I asked. I didn't know this was a vegetarian sandwich and I really should've double checked. Next time I'll be ordering this, but with dutch crunch & salami or some type of meat! BUT the sandwich itself was really good even without the meat, so I'm going to say it's still a win, lol.

The Panda was my boyfriends favorite, and it was pretty packed as well. The flavoring was really intense because there was a lot going on. It comes with pastrami, salami, pepperjack, pepperocini, roasted pepper aioli, & etc! You can see why it was so intense, lol!

We ordered two korean steaks the last time we were here and it was pretty bomb. It was filled with bulgogi meat, but the sauce had an interesting spice to it that I didn't really enjoy too much. But that's just my personal preference -- my boyfriend on the other hand, liked it.

I'd say try the miss piggy with meat & dutch crunch, if you love pesto like I do! I'm definitely coming back to re-do my order next time.

excerpts: I've had the Korean Steak, Barney Rubble, Chicken BBQ, and the Noe St sandwiches.
korean steak.author: Art O.
korean steak.review:
I've had a few sandwiches from this place now and they've all been solid.

I've had the Korean Steak, Barney Rubble, Chicken BBQ, and the Noe St sandwiches.

They're not exactly a bargain but they're made with care and one sandwich is usually way more than enough for a lunch.

The best bet is to call in your order and pick it up since it the line can get long sometimes.

excerpts: I think my favorites are Korean Steak (their signature sandwich),
The Panda, The Freak #55, and @studio_dad.
They are all so flavorful, and they use plenty of meat (unlike Ike's, these days...).
I prefer to order the spicy version of any sandwiches with spice ranges, although that's pretty spicy and maybe too spicy for some folks...
korean steak.author: Tay H.
korean steak.review:
You cannot go wrong with a sandwich from Rhea's - I've yet to have a bad one.  And, they make the PERFECT Dolores Park meal :)

I think my favorites are Korean Steak (their signature sandwich), The Panda, The Freak #55, and @studio_dad.  They are all so flavorful, and they use plenty of meat (unlike Ike's, these days...).  I prefer to order the spicy version of any sandwiches with spice ranges, although that's pretty spicy and maybe too spicy for some folks...  Prices are about right for the quality of the ingredients and the size of the sandwiches - they range from about $10-$12, in most cases.  

Service is pretty quick and the market has plenty of accompaniments for your sandwich - all the typical bodega items, I'd say.  Just make sure to go on the earlier side (they open at 11am) before they run out of Dutch Crunch.

P.S. The Acme Organic Sweet Roll and the Dutch Crunch are the best bread options.  I really didn't like the Toasted French Roll...kind of doughy and bland.

excerpts: I had the Korean Steak and the Buster Posey and both were by far the best sandwiches I've ever had, hands down.
Perfect ratio of ingredients, super juicy meats and an insane amount of flavor.
korean steak.author: Matthew D.
korean steak.review: These guys know how to make sandwiches. I had the Korean Steak and the Buster Posey and both were by far the best sandwiches I've ever had, hands down. Perfect ratio of ingredients, super juicy meats and an insane amount of flavor.

excerpts: * Korean Steak - 3.5 stars
The flavors on this sandwich definitely pop.
And if you ask for spicy, you get the real deal!
They put in jalapeño slices which were actually too much for me.
korean steak.author: Ziyan C.
korean steak.review:
Glad to find another sandwich option near Valencia! It was a sad moment for me when Mission Picnic was closed one random Saturday, so I went to Yelp and just picked the closest option for "sandwiches" in the Mission.

I'd passed by this place so many times (and I think even shopped here once) and had no idea it was a deli in addition to a corner store.

I liked both sandwiches but didn't love them. However, the quality was good enough that I'm interested to go back and find better sandwiches and be able to bump up Rhea's overall rating.

THE SERVICE: They will answer the phone, and they will give accurate estimates on the wait. I really appreciate that!

THE WAIT: I called ahead around 1:30pm on a Saturday and it was about a 30 minute wait for the sandwiches.

THE COST: About $30 total for 2 sandwiches.

See my photos for additional info!

* Korean Steak - 3.5 stars
The flavors on this sandwich definitely pop. And if you ask for spicy, you get the real deal! They put in jalapeño slices which were actually too much for me. However, I found the quality of the meat slices to be low - they weren't quite lean, the texture came out a bit rubbery as it was rather fatty (and not in the good way that some meats can be). 

* The Valencia - 4 stars
Much more classic than the Korean, a little bland if you do a side-by-side comparison, but still very well done. I loved the avocado, and the bread was just perfect. A safe yet delicious go-to.

excerpts: The Korean Steak sandwich a genuine banger.
Highly recommended, and get it spicy.
The steak tastes like actual steak, instead of the sheets of general meat you get at some places.
Go here, get this sandwich, make it spicy, eat it in Dolores Park.
Guaranteed great day.
korean steak.author: Charlie R.
korean steak.review: The Korean Steak sandwich a genuine banger. Highly recommended, and get it spicy. The steak tastes like actual steak, instead of the sheets of general meat you get at some places. Go here, get this sandwich, make it spicy, eat it in Dolores Park. Guaranteed great day. excerpts: After scanning the menu a few times, I debated between the Korean Steak or the 18th Street, which was personally recommended to me.
korean steak.author: Alexander E.
korean steak.review:
I love a great sandwich. I mean who doesn't? As per the recommendation of some co-workers, a co-worker and I decided to give Rhea's a try on this sunny Monday afternoon in San Francisco. Unfortunately Rhea's does not have a website, which means no current menu, but luckily their Yelp page has their sandwich menu. After scanning the menu a few times, I debated between the Korean Steak or the 18th Street, which was personally recommended to me. 

We were advised that Rhea's isn't a sit and eat kind of deli, so we called ahead for pickup. Once we arrived, both sandwiches were ready to go and although there was a small counter to eat, it's not the best place to enjoy your lunch hour. Besides the deli counter, it's your typical liquor corner store and not much else. My 18th Street sandwich ran me $9.

With it being such a nice day out, we took our sandwiches to nearby Dolores Park. As soon as you unwrap the butcher paper, the first thing you'll notice is the portion size. It's not terribly small but I had a feeling it wouldn't be filling either. I will say the sandwich packed plenty of flavor in between the Acme roll. The flavorful sandwich consisted of buffalo chicken, muenster cheese, bacon, baby arugula, red onion, which I opted out of, tomatoes, pickles and a chipotle aioli. 

Even with the abundance of flavors, nothing was overpowering and I enjoyed the sandwich without my usual splash of hot sauce.The recommendation on the sandwich was great and Rhea's is a great spot for a light and fluffy sandwich. However, I was disappointed in the overall size of the sandwich especially given that its coming from a corner store. I don't mind the $10 price point but I expected a bit more for my money. I do however agree with the consensus in that Rhea's makes one mean sandwich, just be sure to pickup some chips on the side. 

Pros:
+ Corner store with a full sandwich/deli counter
+ Large sandwich menu
+ Made to order sandwiches
+ Quick and tasty
+ Affordable prices
+ General corner store with full booze lineup and snacks

Cons:
- No website with full menu
- Small portion size

excerpts: I also tried their famous korean steak from a friend, and it was delicious.
The sandwiches are a little spicy, just the right amount.
The deli also has some pretty great snacks and drinks.
We got some delicious dark chocolate, some fancy crisps, and a bunch of other things.
This place is so recommended, and I will make sure to pick up a sandwich from there every time I go to Dolores park, which happens to be every time I am in the city.
korean steak.author: Riham B.
korean steak.review:
So here is how I got to hear of this place: We wanted to chill at Dolores Park and eat delicious sandwiches. So we called a few days before and ordered around 30 sandwiches (probably). Rhea's couldn't accommodate us. We were all disappointment since the menu had built up so much excitement about these glorious sandwiches. We then called them from Dolores park and ordered 5 sandwiches at a time, and lo and behold, we were able to get our hands on these sandwiches.

I was not disappointed. I ordered the 18th st sandwich, and it was so so good. I also tried their famous korean steak from a friend, and it was delicious. The sandwiches are a little spicy, just the right amount. 
The deli also has some pretty great snacks and drinks. We got some delicious dark chocolate, some fancy crisps, and a bunch of other things. This place is so recommended, and I will make sure to pick up a sandwich from there every time I go to Dolores park, which happens to be every time I am in the city.

excerpts: The Korean Steak (marinated rib eye steak, cheddar cheese, red onions, house pickled red onions & jalapenos, lettuce, chili sauce, garlic aioli, served on acme organic sweet roll) is the must-try
and it's legit spicy and super-flavorful.
The bulgogi is a bit sweet and goes great with the chili sauce.
korean steak.author: Saminda W.
korean steak.review:
Rhea's is up there, definitely in the top 20 joints in the city for sammies.  It's a cross between Lou's in the Richmond and (the original) Ike's in the Castro: inventive and unique sandwich creations done up by some choice bread (never sleep on the bread, yo).

The Korean Steak (marinated rib eye steak, cheddar cheese, red onions, house pickled red onions & jalapenos, lettuce, chili sauce, garlic aioli, served on acme organic sweet roll) is the must-try and it's legit spicy and super-flavorful.  The bulgogi is a bit sweet and goes great with the chili sauce.  I like the Buster Posey ( pastrami (locally made) wrapped in pastrami, melted pepper jack, creamy slaw, roasted pepper & garlic aioli, kc style bbq sauce served on toasted french roll) because it's made with heaping cuts of pastrami and the aioli and bbq sauce pair perfectly with it.

While both are delicious as heck, the Korean steak one trumps them all for me.

Top notch sandwiches!

The bread was perfect, the meat was perfect, the spice level and sauce was absolutely amazing and the pickled red onions and jalepenos were still crunchy. Definitely a WOW factor

I would've given them 5 stars had the sandwich not been so small for $13.09

korean steak.review:

I saw a yelp photo from a few years back that showed instructions for ordering were posted at the deli but nothing was posted when I paid a visit this past weekend. 

Order the korean steak sandwich! There's lots of steak and it's very flavorful, and you can order it as spicy as you'd like. And the Acme bread is incredible! There are tons of other sandwich options so there's definitely something for everybody.

Their sandwiches are amazing. I really enjoyed the Korean Steak sandwich. The shop also sells chips and drinks. Its the perfect place to pick up everything you need for a nice picnic at Dolores Park (its like a 5 minute walk from here). 

The Korean Steak comes on a sour dough like bread but its not as hard or sour. I got it without cheese because I saw someone else's review that suggested it would taste better without it. The sauce that comes with the sandwich makes it moist and it comes with a spicy kick. You can get it mild, medium or hot. The meat was marinated and thinly sliced so the sandwich held together very well. The vegetables are fresh and complements the other flavors of the sandwich.

It can be a little wait before you receive your sandwich though. I came here on a Saturday around noon and we waited around 20 minutes. I didn't know there was a lot of people ahead of me because majority of the customers walk around outside while waiting.

korean steak.author: Maya B.
korean steak.review:
Split the Korean steak sandwich with a friend today. Not the first time we've been there and certainly won't be the last time. The Korean steak sandwich is of course, Rhea's signature sandwich and for good reason. We got ours in less than five minutes (Wednesday, cloudy, lunchtime; your mileage may vary on a warm weekend when everyone and everyone wants a sammie to take to Dolores).

It's immensely flavorful, unique, and the flavors are well-balanced. You'll get notes of umami, sweet, salty, sour, spicy and creamy with each bite. The bread they use is excellent and the portions are hearty (again, we split a whole sandwich yet both of us were satisfied). We ordered it medium spicy and it was the perfect rendition of medium. The heat kicked in slowly but was never overwhelming. 

I've been a Rhea's customer for almost 17 years (as long as I've lived in the Mission) and I remember when it really was just a corner store (albeit a well-run one even back in the day). For several year now, it's been a corner store *plus* a fantastic sandwich deli. 

The Korean steak sandwich is a go-to for good reason, but the entire sandwich menu is creative and worth checking out. Never had a bad sammie but when I explore other options, I always want to reserve the option of swapping half of whatever I'm trying out for half of the Korean steak and thus I always eat there with at least one other person.

James Choi is the fourth owner of Rhea's according to the Check Please episode that highlighted them (and I happened to walk by, back when they filmed that episode years ago; so fun to watch both the filming of it and the actual episode). His parents ran it before he took over and reinvented it a bit, for the better. Super nice, very genuine guy and so are the people that work there (link below is to a profile of "Corner Store George"):

http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/cityexposed/article/Corner-store-is-his-vocation-2309673.php

A neighborhood gem that's also a worthy destination even for people who don't live nearby.

korean steak.author: Ed U.
korean steak.review:
The primary reason Jamie W. and I headed over to Rhea's after hanging out on a lazy Sunday afternoon at Dolores Park was to try the Korean Steak Sandwich. I was on the Chefs' Feed app and read Foreign Cinema chef Gayle Pirie's rave about it, so I thought it was worth us heading over there to try it. The place was swamped with customers waiting in line to order sandwiches, and much to our chagrin, they were sold out of the Korean Steak Sandwich. But instead of leaving in a huff - a specialty of mine - we saw there were quite a few sandwiches that sounded tempting. The challenge was reviewing the menu taped on 8 x 11 sheets in front of the sandwich makers because there was a queue of  hungry people in the way.

I believe it was the first day for the young guy taking the orders at the cash register, and he was overwhelmed by the chaos. However, he kept a sunny disposition which I genuinely appreciated since a few of the customers were on the high maintenance side. Jamie ended up ordering the $7.95 Harrison Street, a hot pastrami and cheddar cheese sandwich with red onion, lettuce, tomatoes, pickles, pepperoncini, spicy brown mustard and chipotle aioli all stuffed into an Acme organic roll (see photo). Hearty stuff and quite delicious. Mine was simpler and quite good, too...the $7.95 Boar's Head Roast Beef with spicy mustard, lettuce, tomato and mayo, all in a fresh Dutch crunch roll (see photo). We managed to snag two stools at the small counter in front and let others envy us for our gigantic sandwiches.

FOOD - 4 stars...huge, fresh sandwiches are enough to satisfy anyone in need
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...just a mini-mart with a sandwich counter
SERVICE - 4 stars...the new guy did good
TOTAL - 4 stars...definitely need to come back for that Korean Steak Sandwich now that it's on our radar

My first job involved working in the food industry, so I know how annoying it can be to take that last order right when you're about to close up shop. I admit that I was THAT customer the first time I went to Rhea's Deli. I rushed over and made it just in time. I have to give them props because they were still gracious and accommodating to the last customers that trickled in before closing time. 

I ordered the chicken katsu on a French roll only because they sold out of their Korean steak sandwich and acme rolls for the day. Understandable considering I came at the last minute. Although the katsu sandwich was my second choice, I was more than happy with it. I had to take it to go but the bread still held up to the katsu and toppings for the most part. It was rather large so I could only finish half. Take note that if you order your sandwich mild, it doesn't come with jalapeños. 

Rhea's Deli has so many sandwiches to choose from. Grab a order sheet and customize your sandwich to your liking. If I lived closer and parking wasn't such a hassle, I'd be a regular. I'd definitely return nonetheless!

excerpts: The Korean Steak sandwich is great, it's a nice diversion from the standard.
The Katsu is also really good.
korean steak.author: Ben M.
korean steak.review:
I love the fact that old ladies come in here to buy 12 packs of bud. It's a locals market, the sandwiches they offer are not just typical deli sandwiches. The Korean Steak sandwich is great, it's a nice diversion from the standard. The Katsu is also really good. The more typical sandwiches all look good but why stray from the best. 

Call in your order ahead and give them plenty of time. The place can get fairly busy. 

The beer selection is fairy normal, a good variety.

excerpts: I had the Korean steak sandwich and the flavor was alright
but it wasn't spectacular or mind blowing.
korean steak.author: Tiff C.
korean steak.review:
Heard about Rhea's through Yelp for the longest time and finally got to try it the other week. This place is ALRIGHT... I don't know what's going on with all the raving reviews... but y'all have obviously not had a REAL GOOD SANDWICH.. I had the Korean steak sandwich and the flavor was alright but it wasn't spectacular or mind blowing. It was also HELLA SMALL... for $9.00.. way overpriced... what a RIP OFF..

OVER HYPED!

excerpts:
tables available and no wait for our food : ) 

Between my friend and I, we had the korean steak sandwich and a burger with blue cheese.
korean steak.author: Benny N.
korean steak.review:
I feel a little weird making this post with so many 5s and 4s. My friend that I went with gave them a 5. And just yesterday, I gave another perennial Yelp fav 3 stars. Well here goes...

I was surprised to find parking literally in front of this place, and on a Saturday too! I'll chalk it up to my good parking karma. We walk in and there are a few people there, but tables available and no wait for our food : ) 

Between my friend and I, we had the korean steak sandwich and a burger with blue cheese. I thought the flavor on the KSS was ok. The meat to me seemed a little on the over cooked side. The bread was good and I can see how if the meat had been better prepared, that this would be pretty bomb. The burger I thought was your typical standard GOOD burger. The blue cheese was the highlight of the burger.

excerpts:
-hot salsa, jalepenos smothered other flavors
-would get mild sauce or the korean steak sammie next time

crumbs:
-online menu pricing outdated, most signature sammies 9+
-counter
korean steak.author: Victor G.
korean steak.review:
Rhea's Deli makes fab sammies. (so i hear). the market sells gourmet juices, breakfast cereals, micobrews, wines, snacks, chocolates, chips, ice cream.....

drill: fill out sammie order sheet, pay at counter, wait for named to be called (20 minutes?)

eats: katsu sammie(9.45)
-"lightly fried chicken in panko crumbs, w/rhea's coleslaw, housed pickled red onions, jalepenos, spicy aiolo, tangy katsu sauce" on acme roll
-got it medium sauce, big mistake, too hot
-chicken portion thin, mostly tasted veggies.
-hot salsa, jalepenos smothered other flavors
-would get mild sauce or the korean steak sammie next time

crumbs:
-online menu pricing outdated, most signature sammies 9+
-counter persons very helpful, courteious , 5 stars
-beers, juices, not priced, wines are.
-metered parking hard to find....many meter person trolling
-pricing cheap than at the cafe.
-boar's head meats used.
-only a few seats on a bench in the far end.

excerpts: For all you carnivores, Korean Steak and Dolores are always solid!
korean steak.author: Olivia C.
korean steak.review:
Better than Ike's. Rhea, you are bae.

I first discovered this little sandwich spot when completing a writing workshop at the nearby 826 Valencia. It is tucked away in a liquor store, but it is very clean and friendly. A great place to get lunch with sandwiches that are supremely flavorful and filling.

Honestly, everything I have tried here is great. For all you carnivores, Korean Steak and Dolores are always solid!

While you wait for your sandwich, explore the quirky, eclectic neighboring stores (shoutout to Paxton Gate for taxidermy-inspired home decor and 826 Valencia for writing and pirate supplies). 

PRO-TIP: Get the Dolores sandwich and walk 7 minutes to eat it in Dolores Park.

excerpts: I chose the popular Korean Steak Sandwich.

For $8.99, the sandwich had a thinly sliced rib-eye steak marinated and grilled with a Korean twist, with grilled onion, cheese, lettuce, a tangy garlic aioli sauce and a spicy chili sauce in a toasted Acme Roll.
This is a great tasting sandwich with the entire key ingredients blended well together.
korean steak.author: Matt G.
korean steak.review:
Initially, I thought this place was just an ordinary liquor store. 

Wrong...there is also a deli inside here as well. 

Only open for lunch, the unique deli makes signature sandwiches with great names of some of the neighboring streets of our beloved city. Names of sandwiches like Noe Street, Valencia Street and Cunningham Place make this deli very utmost and pleasing on my future visit(s). 

On this visit on my debut, you need to place your order on a sheet on what you want on your sandwich. I chose the popular Korean Steak Sandwich. For $8.99, the sandwich had a thinly sliced rib-eye steak marinated and grilled with a Korean twist, with grilled onion, cheese, lettuce, a tangy garlic aioli sauce and a spicy chili sauce in a toasted Acme Roll. This is a great tasting sandwich with the entire key ingredients blended well together. This hot sandwich must be eaten immediately. 

Depending the time of the day, the wait for sandwich can take up to 15-20 minutes to prepare. While waiting, the entertaining bunch of happy workers behind the deli were serenading to any songs played on KISS FM while making our sandwiches. "I just hope they don't pursue a singing career and quit their day job at Rhea's Deli!"

They also have a good selection of beverages and beers at reasonable price.  

I like my sandwich from here. You can also call in your sandwich(s) ahead of time to avoid the long wait.

excerpts: After hearing the hype I decided to try Rhea's Korean Steak Sandwich on a Friday afternoon.
The Deli counter is to the left with all the descriptions of their sandwiches.
The Korean Steak comes with 3 options of spiciness and I opted for medium.
I waited around for 10 or 15 minutes when they finally called my name.
It was difficult to find anywhere to stand while waiting and felt like I was constantly in the way of the workers and other shoppers.
The Korean Steak comes with 3 options of spiciness and I opted for medium.
I waited around for 10 or 15 minutes when they finally called my name.
It was difficult to find anywhere to stand while waiting and felt like I was constantly in the way of the workers and other shoppers.
The flavor was excellent (not what I was expecting but awesome) but the bread had gotten all soggy with grease from the steak, which was a turnoff.
It also cost $11 which is a bit high for an average sized sandwich.
korean steak.author: Shane E.
korean steak.review:
After hearing the hype I decided to try Rhea's Korean Steak Sandwich on a Friday afternoon.  The Deli counter is to the left with all the descriptions of their sandwiches.  However, you do order using one of their preprinted paper slips that are located next to the cash register (right next to the door), which is also where you pay for your sandwich.

The Korean Steak comes with 3 options of spiciness and I opted for medium.  I waited around for 10 or 15 minutes when they finally called my name.  It was difficult to find anywhere to stand while waiting and felt like I was constantly in the way of the workers and other shoppers.   I carried the sandwich home about 5 blocks and devoured it.

The flavor was excellent (not what I was expecting but awesome) but the bread had gotten all soggy with grease from the steak, which was a turnoff.  It also cost $11 which is a bit high for an average sized sandwich.  The medium spiciness was legit and didn't need to order it 'spicy' just to feel it.

Overall they make great sandwiches without the bells and whistles.  I'll come back only if it's convenient though.  I fear a 40 minute wait if I don't show up when they open or don't call ahead.

excerpts: In particular, their Korean Steak Sandwich and Pork Katsu Sandwich.
If I had to pick my favorite between the two, I probably would pick the Korean Steak simply because it had a nice blend of sweet and spicy flavor.
If I had to pick my favorite between the two, I probably would pick the Korean Steak simply because it had a nice blend of sweet and spicy flavor.
That's not to say that the Pork Katsu Sandwich was bad, that sandwich itself was delicious simply because I have a thing for fried stuff.
Though it may be hard for me to ignore the Korean Steak.
Though it may be hard for me to ignore the Korean Steak.
korean steak.author: Rodney H.
korean steak.review:
A little to the party, but I was finally able to stop by Rhea's Deli & Market to try their tasty sandwiches that everyone's been raving about.  In particular, their Korean Steak Sandwich and Pork Katsu Sandwich.  Really good stuff!!!

Just take a look at these (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=IweGUk8obqiACeWXoMJT3w)  It's edible art!!  If I had to pick my favorite between the two, I probably would pick the Korean Steak simply because it had a nice blend of sweet and spicy flavor.  That's not to say that the Pork Katsu Sandwich was bad, that sandwich itself was delicious simply because I have a thing for fried stuff.

They have a huge menu of sandwiches as well and I would say that they're giving Ike's Place a run for their money.  So far from what I've had, I'm willing to go back and try the rest of them.  Though it may be hard for me to ignore the Korean Steak.

Definitely give these guys a try if you're in the Mission!

excerpts: If you're feeling bold the Korean Steak is where it's at.
korean steak.author: Danielle L.
korean steak.review:
So I'm a sandwich snob. Don't you dare give me something that I can make on my own or that isn't effing toasted. That being said, I'm SO into this place. 

If you want something seriously delicious for the lunch munchies, Rhea's will not dissapoint. They are massive and well thought out vehicles of greatness into your face. Famous among the Mission crowd; ideal for a grab and go when you're headed to Dolores Park for the day. My personal favorite is the Dolores, but I also go for a Valencia from time to time. If you're feeling bold the Korean Steak is where it's at. 

On the weekends you can (will) run into some wait time, but you have the option of calling in ahead (so take advantage of that).

excerpts: KOREAN STEAK SANDWICH ($8.99):
This is the "famous" sandwich that everyone talks about.
It was tasty but nothing crazy and out of this world.
I ordered this without the cheddar cheese.
I prefer my bulgogi (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulgogi) without the funky taste of cheddar or any cheeses for that matter.
The tender soy-marinated rib-eye had just the right amount of meat to lettuce ratio.
I like this one better than my steak sandwich since I have a hankering for fried meats.
I only got the Korean Steak bc
I only got the Korean Steak bc
korean steak.author: Cin T.
korean steak.review:
I've had this deli bookmarked for a while, so it was definitely on my list to check out while in SF. And it's located only a few blocks from where I'm staying in the Mission District, how perfect is that?!

It took a while for the sandwiches to arrive, surprising it was still crunchy and delicious, right down to the last bite. Loved the crunchy organic roll. 

KOREAN STEAK SANDWICH ($8.99): 
  This is the "famous" sandwich that everyone talks about. It was tasty but nothing crazy and out of this world.
 I ordered this without the cheddar cheese. I prefer my bulgogi (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulgogi) without the funky taste of cheddar or any cheeses for that matter. The tender soy-marinated rib-eye had just the right amount of meat to lettuce ratio. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/humRe1SGupNdDJUxEdDmMg?select=PRtK3t-9xVLzIEhCf8DHyw

The chopped lettuce, grilled AND pickled red onions, jalapenos gave the sammie a nice texture when paired with the soft beef. 

The tangy garlic aioli had flecks of red chilies in it. It wasn't spicy enough for me, but it had a nice kick. Bulgogi in a bun, can't go wrong!

PORK KATSU SANDWICH ($8.19): My favorite one!!
 Paul got this one and I managed to take a bite out of it. I like this one better than my steak sandwich since I have a hankering for fried meats. I only got the Korean Steak bc everyone raved about it. 

The thinly pounded pork loin is covered in panko bread crumbs and fried to a golden crisp. Despite the thinness, the pork still retained it's moisture.

The katsu was topped with Rhea's homemade coleslaw (lacking mayo, which I liked), pickled red onions, jalapenos and a spicy aioli. There was also a light drizzle of their tangy katsu sauce. The katsu sauce reminds me of a sweeter version of Arby's bbq sauce.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/humRe1SGupNdDJUxEdDmMg?select=5B9LBUEngWTYtuPAoHR9fg

CHICKEN KATSU SANDWICH ($8.19)
 My friend Niki doesn't eat pork so she got the chicken version of the katsu sandwich. Aside from the chicken, everything else is the same as the above mentioned breaded pork sandwich. The juicy chicken patty is a little thicker than the pork.  
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/humRe1SGupNdDJUxEdDmMg?select=jPsUtO_b0j9Rq6CrCxTZTg

excerpts: From the Korean Steak Sandwich (which is a MUST have) to the Wonder Woman, every sandwich is delicious and filled with a wonderful combination of flavor, spice, meats and cheese.
After having five different sandwiches, on my sixth visit I decided it was time to try the Korean Steak Sandwich.
After having five different sandwiches, on my sixth visit I decided it was time to try the Korean Steak Sandwich.
I nearly broke my jaw in excitement in taking the first bite (the sandwich height is approximately 6 inches) and was greeted with a steak filled explosion of flavor and spice - YUM!
korean steak.author: Lauren B.
korean steak.review:
Hands down, BEST sandwich in the city.  From the Korean Steak Sandwich (which is a MUST have) to the Wonder Woman, every sandwich is delicious and filled with a wonderful combination of flavor, spice, meats and cheese.

After having five different sandwiches, on my sixth visit I decided it was time to try the Korean Steak Sandwich.  I nearly broke my jaw in excitement in taking the first bite (the sandwich height is approximately 6 inches) and was greeted with a steak filled explosion of flavor and spice - YUM!

My roommate is a vegetarian and she absolutely loves the Vegetarian BBQ Chicken Sandwich - best fake meat around, she says!

Whatever you decide, and believe me it's a difficult choice...you will not be disappointed.

excerpts: I guess the right thing to do as most first timers here is to to try the Korean Steak Sandwich.
The crusty roll made this sandwich hold together all the ingredients perfectly without spilling out to much.
Just the right amount of heat (mild) makes it a top winner on my list of top sandwiches in the city.
korean steak.author: Wolfy W.
korean steak.review:
Rhea's was on my must try list way too long not to try for over a year. I guess the right thing to do as most first timers here is to to try the Korean Steak Sandwich. The crusty roll made this sandwich hold together all the ingredients perfectly without spilling out to much. Just the right amount of heat (mild) makes it a top winner on my list of top sandwiches in the city. Generous amount of thinly sliced beef, red onions, garlic chile sauce, cheddar cheese and lettuce, Korean styles that is.

The noon crowds, as I learned by others, is to called your order in or the waiting time is 20+ minutes. Yes, it is worth the waiting, as most great eats required you to have patients. I'll be back......

excerpts: My brother ordered the Korean steak sandwich and loved it.
korean steak.author: Maleenee B.
korean steak.review:
Amazing sandwiches. I created my own sandwich: I ordered the cheese and avocado sandwich with veggie chicken. Absolutely delicious. It was stacked with avocado and all of the fillings and constructed perfectly. 

Taste and size wise, it's just as delicious as Ike's Place. 

However, Rhea's beats Ike's in:
- price: $5 for the cheese and guacamole sandwich, plus $1 for the faux meat (which was tasty, although next time I'll probably get it without it because I like fresher rather than heartier sandwiches. 
- customization: you can build your own sandwich
- line: there were only 3 people ahead of me (granted per sandwich they are on the slower side)

One of the best sandwiches I've had. And you can take it to Dolores Park which is 2 blocks down. I came here after hiking in Oakland and it was the perfect post-hike meal. 

My brother ordered the Korean steak sandwich and loved it. His mouth was burning by the end though. 

FYI they have a $10 minimum for credit cards!

Ok, so maybe that's more than one word, but there's no doubt that the Korean Steak Sandwich at Rhea's is hands-down the BEST sandwich I've ever had in my 29 years!
Ok, so maybe that's more than one word, but there's no doubt that the Korean Steak Sandwich at Rhea's is hands-down the BEST sandwich I've ever had in my 29 years!
So I had my doubts about going to Rhea's for their Korean Steak Sandwich, especially in such an unassuming place as in the Mission.
But, boy was I WRONG.

Being the recipient of the 2010 SF Bay Guardian Best of the Bay Award, there was no question that I was ordering the much hyped Korean Steak Sandwich - Medium Spicy ($8.45).

No words can really explain how mouth-watering the Korean Steak Sandwich was and it's just something that you will have to "experience" for yourself.
korean steak.author: Cherylynn N.
korean steak.review:
What's the BEST word to describe the KOREAN STEAK STANDWICH at Rhea's?

* * * * * * *P H U C K I N'  B O M B D I G G I T Y* * * * * * *

Ok, so maybe that's more than one word, but there's no doubt that the Korean Steak Sandwich at Rhea's is hands-down the BEST sandwich I've ever had in my 29 years!

Let me preface by saying that I haven't had many good experiences with Asian Fusion food especially street food because the authentic bold flavors are always lacking. So I had my doubts about going to Rhea's for their Korean Steak Sandwich, especially in such an unassuming place as in the Mission. But, boy was I WRONG. Don't be fooled because the Korean Steak Sandwich will be the best ORGASMIC sandwiches experiences you will ever have! Way better than Ike's...

On Thursday, December 30th, I came to Rhea's at 12ish after having just finished with a Dr.'s appointment nearby. 

Upon walking in, I was a bit confused on the ordering process especially when the directions on how to order was blocked by another person. So, I stood there for a good several minutes until the person left and I finally noticed the directions.

1) Get a sandwich order form at the sandwich counter.

2) Choose from their signature sandwiches like the Korean Steak and Chicken Katsu Sandwich or make your own by choosing your own bread, meat, cheese, and condiments. 

3) Give your order form to the cashier and pay for your sandwich (CC's accepted) before your order is processed.

Free delivery is offered in the Mission area ($10 minimum) with a $3 surcharge past 9th street and Market towards Duboce streets.

There's a small counter for four in the market and a small bench outside to munch your sandwich. 

Being the recipient of the 2010 SF Bay Guardian Best of the Bay Award, there was no question that I was ordering the much hyped Korean Steak Sandwich - Medium Spicy ($8.45). It's NO wonder that it won an award because the sandwich was K I L L E R!

Grilled and marinated bulgogi piled over 2 inches high, layered with crisp spicy kimchi, sweet red onions, spicy jalapenos, chili garlic sauce, garlic aioli, and cheddar cheese sandwiched between a toasted Acme roll. The first bite was like an orchestrated symphony of flavors and textures in my mouth. The crisp and chewy bread led to the savory, tender and sweet bulgogi with a hint of gingery and garlicy goodness. The kimchi and chili garlic sauce added a fiery kick that was cooled down by both the creamy and rich aioli and thick slices of sharp cheddar. 

There was no shortage of bold spices and flavors and THIS is how Asian Fusion food should taste like. No words can really explain how mouth-watering the Korean Steak Sandwich was and it's just something that you will have to "experience" for yourself.

Do note that the sandwich tends to get soggy from the juiciness of the bulgogi, so make sure to eat it ASAP! 

Since I used the holiday season as an excuse to derail off my diet, I don't know when I'll be able to return to Rhea's. But I know when I do,  I will be throwing my carb inhibitions out the door and get the Chicken Katsu Sandwich too. :X

P.S. - Rhea's sells the hard to find and highly addictive Cadbury Flake and Aero. 

Killer sandwiches and delectable Cadbury chocolates? Talk about all sorts of Carb Diet FAIL! *sigh*

excerpts: I've read quite a lot of good reviews about this place before actually trying the Korean steak sandwich for the first time.
I have to admit, it was decent, but nothing earth-shattering.
Sour dough bread is fresh, and the steak is good but a little soggy.
Make sure to get spicy to get the authentic taste.
korean steak.author: Phillip K.
korean steak.review:
I've read quite a lot of good reviews about this place before actually trying the Korean steak sandwich for the first time. I have to admit, it was decent, but nothing earth-shattering. Sour dough bread is fresh, and the steak is good but a little soggy. Make sure to get spicy to get the authentic taste. It will energize you. 

I almost feel like giving this place three and a half stars because of its uniqueness, but again, i paid $13 for my sandwich so it's kind of pricey. 

For the location, this place is great and I can see why a lot of people go here. It's kind of like Roxie's in the sense that it's a liquor store with a deli inside. There is also a table to eat with a few stools to the right of the entrance. Certainly not a lot of room, but conducive to someone who goes solo. Overall, I think it's worth a try if your around the neighborhood with Dolores Park nearby. They also offer a variety of selections to choose from. 

A good place to experiment.

excerpts: The Buster Posey made me completely reconsider having sworn off pastrami and the Korean steak is unreal good too.
korean steak.author: Will R.
korean steak.review:
The perfect San Francisco day consists of a Dolores sandwich from Rhea's consumed at nearby Dolores park. Not just because it's a quintessentially San Franciscan thing to do, but because it's one of the best sandwiches you will eat and the park provides the perfect place to reflect on exactly how awesome it is. It's kind of an edgy take on the traditional Thanksgiving leftovers sandwich, with spicy turkey, cranberry sauce, and jalapenos, and they get it totally right.

It's pretty difficult to go wrong with any of the sandwich options at Rhea's. The Buster Posey made me completely reconsider having sworn off pastrami and the Korean steak is unreal good too.

Pro tip: call ahead 20 mins to order and avoid the in-person wait around lunchtime.

excerpts:
I think I should have ordered the Korean Steak Sandwich. 

I would recommend:
The Korean Steak Sandwich
Calling in your order
Not going in and ordering if you are super hungry or need to eat immediately.

I would recommend:
The Korean Steak Sandwich
Calling in your order
Not going in and ordering if you are super hungry or need to eat immediately.
korean steak.author: Tara H.
korean steak.review:
Wandering around The Mission, I remembered that my coworker had once brought us sandwiches from Rhea's Deli & Market. Which were delicious AND huge.

I head over and it's busy. I figure out I want the Noe. Place my order. Then I wait. Then a guy with a banjo comes in and starts to play. The guy at the register offers him a free sandwich if he plays the whole time (while he is in the store). He does. Banjo dude get's his sandwich. Some other people who came in after me get their sandwiches. All the while the guy at the register is talking sh*t and busting everyone's balls. Entertaining....for the first 30 minutes.

I waited for 41 minutes. At this point, I'm actually experiencing a low blood sugar episode and am starting to feel faint.

I get the sandwich. The sandwich was...okay. I ate one half and gave the other to my flatmate. I think I should have ordered the Korean Steak Sandwich. 

I would recommend:
The Korean Steak Sandwich
Calling in your order
Not going in and ordering if you are super hungry or need to eat immediately.

(Note: The three stars are more a reflection of the time it took to get my sandwich and the fact that five people behind me in line got served before me.)

excerpts: As for my first sandwich there (Korean Steak), it was just so-so.
The bread was not inspired--was it ciabatta from costco/la brea?
And while the meat (bul go gi) was ok, it didn't really integrate well with the cheddar, jalapenos or anything else in the sandwich.
Korean fusion at its best tastes like the Kogi truck or Bok Ssam.
But I felt like this embodiment was just a bunch of ingredients that were thrown together.
How about a kochujang mayo? or rice vinegar/kimchee slaw?
korean steak.author: Philip L.
korean steak.review:
After having gone to Davy Jone's in Marin for some mind blowing sandwiches, I was inspired to try some closer-to-home joints.  Rhea's is one of the highest rated in SF, and a place that I've always meant to try because of Korean tacos advertised out front. (Apparently one of the owners may be Korean.)

The service was friendly, competent, and quick.  I know some reviews mention how long the wait can be, but at 2pm, the wait is five minutes from store entry to sandwich receiving.

As for my first sandwich there (Korean Steak), it was just so-so.  The bread was not inspired--was it ciabatta from costco/la brea?  And while the meat (bul go gi) was ok, it didn't really integrate well with the cheddar, jalapenos or anything else in the sandwich.  Korean fusion at its best tastes like the Kogi truck or Bok Ssam.  But I felt like this embodiment was just a bunch of ingredients that were thrown together.  How about a kochujang mayo? or rice vinegar/kimchee slaw?  that would be more impressive.

Clearly people like the sandwiches--at least 5 people were eating at 2 pm.  But I think I'll stick with Davy Jones, Genova Deli...

excerpts: Korean steak sandwich: piquant soy sauce/garlic marinade on the bulgogi.
I had to stop after two bites because there was so much fat.
korean steak.author: Fancypants X.
korean steak.review:
In the 90's, a group of people hanging out in front of a liquor store usually meant trouble; cops flashed their lights, megaphone voices ordered the crowd to disperse. 

Now, a group of people hanging out in front of a liquor store means there's only six seats at the counter inside and facebook/instagram status updates have lured everyone & they mama to try some hyped-up deli sandwich.

Buster Posey sandwich: pastrami w/ pepper jack. Loved the ACME roll & thicker cut of lean pastrami. Would definitely order this again, but without the cheese because it didn't add any extra deliciousness for all the extra calories. 

Korean steak sandwich: piquant soy sauce/garlic marinade on the bulgogi. I had to stop after two bites because there was so much fat. We ordered it "medium" spicy & it had a delicious amount of heat. 

Their sandwich accoutrements are amazing, with a variety of spicy and garlicky spreads, there's a lot of goodness going on between those two buns!

excerpts: We had the Korean Steak, Lexington, and the Panda.
Each sando was as good as the other but with totally different tastes.
If I could give 10, no 20 stars, I would.
It was THAT good....
NOTE:
The wait for the sandwiches was 25 minutes
and I heard them giving 30-35 minute
wait times to customers coming in.
Call your order in before you go and save yourself
a 1/2 hr wait.
They are worth the wait
but if we were in a hurry we would have left.
korean steak.author: T S.
korean steak.review:
Literally the best sandwiches I have ever had.  I constantly try to find hole-in-the-wall sandwich places to discover and this is by far my favorite.  I am a huge fan of Star Meats in Berkeley, Bakesale Betty's, Market & Rye, and Giordanos.  However, the flavor in these sandwiches is incredible!  We had the Korean Steak, Lexington, and the Panda.  Each sando was as good as the other but with totally different tastes.  If I could give 10, no 20 stars, I would.  It was THAT good....
NOTE:  The wait for the sandwiches was 25 minutes and I heard them giving 30-35 minute wait times to customers coming in.  Call your order in before you go and save yourself a 1/2 hr wait.  They are worth the wait but if we were in a hurry we would have left.

excerpts: Next time, the Korean steak sandwich will be my next go getter.
I highly advise not going during lunch hour and good luck finding parking, it's tough!
The market also sells my favorite Simply Lemonade with raspberry drink.
Perfect combination!
korean steak.author: Danster L.
korean steak.review:
Finally I got to try Rhea's Deli after several attempts. The last 2 times I tried to go to Rhea's is because I could not find parking and did not know the deli was closed after 7pm. (I went once at 9pm and the market was open but not the deli.) Finally, I got to try it last week and it was quite good.

I had tried the chicken katsu sandwich which is slathered with their slaw and a garlic aioli sauce on an Acme roll. The sandwich was quite good but small for being nearly $9.50. I want to try the other sandwiches and see if quality surpasses quantity. But I was still hungry after the sandwich. Next time, the Korean steak sandwich will be my next go getter. I highly advise not going during lunch hour and good luck finding parking, it's tough! The market also sells my favorite Simply Lemonade with raspberry drink. Perfect combination!

excerpts: Got the Korean steak sandwich, which was really good.
The steak is intensely marinated, and the flavor pairs really well with the onions and chili sauce.
A delicious, filling sandwich that's well worth the price.
korean steak.author: Simon L.
korean steak.review: Got the Korean steak sandwich, which was really good.  The steak is intensely marinated, and the flavor pairs really well with the onions and chili sauce.  A delicious, filling sandwich that's well worth the price.

excerpts: We got the Korean Steak Sandwich and the Dolores and both were so satisfying and SO spicy.
We preferred the Korean Steak Sandwich more but, both are delicious.
We preferred the Korean Steak Sandwich more but, both are delicious.
Be warned, if you can't tolerate spicy food, be sure to mark "mild" on your Korean Steak Sandwich
(I was trigger happy and didn't see the option
so, I think they gave me the hottest).
Be warned, if you can't tolerate spicy food, be sure to mark "mild" on your Korean Steak Sandwich
(I was trigger happy and didn't see the option
so, I think they gave me the hottest).
korean steak.author: Stephanie L.
korean steak.review:
Great sandwich place in the Mission! With so many delis and food options in SF, you really can't go wrong and Rhea's didn't fall short of my expectations! We got the Korean Steak Sandwich and the Dolores and both were so satisfying and SO spicy. 

Both sandwiches are pretty meaty and come on delicious, freshly baked bread and loaded with toppings. We preferred the Korean Steak Sandwich more but, both are delicious. Be warned, if you can't tolerate spicy food, be sure to mark "mild" on your Korean Steak Sandwich (I was trigger happy and didn't see the option so, I think they gave me the hottest). The Dolores came loaded with jalapeno peppers as well so, my mouth was on fire by the time we finished our sammies.

Sandwiches are about $10/each so, it's a bit pricey but, it's big serving size and it'll leave you stuffed. There are also unlimited amount of chips/drinks/alcohol since it's a convenience store so, be sure to grab some with your meal. 

Customer service was interestingly really good for being a deli/liquor store. The guys behind the counter were helpful and friendly. 

On a sunny day, sandwiches from Rhea's and a short walk to Dolores Park would make for the best picnic in SF!

excerpts: Korean Steak Sandwich - $8.99 - One of the more popular sandwiches
so I had to try it, plus who doesn't like ribeye slices in a sandwich?
The meat has been marinated in a soy sauce garlic, ginger, honey and other spices.
I didn't takes a lot of ginger which is a plus for me, and it did just have a hint of the honey.
The veggies included is lettuce and a very nice pickled red onion with jalapenos and fresh red onions.
The sammie is sauced up with their garlic aioli on the organic acme roll.
korean steak.author: Andrew L.
korean steak.review:
I've been here a total of three times now and feel very comfortable giving this place 4 stars. You are not going to get a "high end, luxurious" sandwich such as Darwin's... more of the blue collar type with a shimmy twist. Here's what I've sample so far

The Harrison - $7.45 -  Hot Pastrami with cheddar cheese, red onions, lettuce, tomatoes, pickles, pepperoncini with spicy mustard and chipotle aioli. I believe the meat is Boar's head which is always a good thing. Not excessively lined with fat yet not too lean where it's completely dry. All the veggies were fresh and there was only a hint of the mustard. Very mild spice from the chipotle. Their acme organic rolls is also very tasty.

Marinated Veggie Steak - $7.45 - This was a true surprise. I'm usually not a big fan of meat substitutes but this is the real deal. The flavor and texture is almost like a Korean marinated meatball. I could eat this and not feel like a wimp! I can't remember the veggies, but I believe it has lettuce, tomatoes and pickles with possible a garlic aioli. 

Korean Steak Sandwich - $8.99 - One of the more popular sandwiches so I had to try it, plus who doesn't like ribeye slices in a sandwich? The meat has been marinated in a soy sauce garlic, ginger, honey and other spices. I didn't takes a lot of ginger which is a plus for me, and it did just have a hint of the honey. The veggies included is lettuce and a very nice pickled red onion with jalapenos and fresh red onions. The sammie is sauced up with their garlic aioli on the organic acme roll. I can see why this is popular, it's quite good especially if you like spicy steak sandwiches.

I'll be back here at least a couple more times. Since their Veggie Steak was really good, they have another vegetarian sammie, the Vegetarian BBQ Chicken which comes with some a chicken drumstick, red/white cabbage with carrots, pickled red onions (yum!), jalapenos, chili garlic sauce and roasted red pepper aioli for $8.19

excerpts: ...... Korean steak sandwich in the world.
and she's right about the Korean steak sandwich being a masterpiece.
and she's right about the Korean steak sandwich being a masterpiece.
The Korean steak sandwich completely creates an addictive taste and flavor sensation.
The Korean steak sandwich completely creates an addictive taste and flavor sensation.
Marinated steak (honey, soy sauce, spices), garlic aioli, hot sauce + pickled jalapeno, with three types of onions, on a warmed acme roll, coughing, sneezing,
so you can sleep medicine!
This sandwich IS the Nyquil that puts my man food appetite to rest.
korean steak.author: Earl G.
korean steak.review:
Places like this is seriously what Yelp was made for. 

I would have never thought that this totally unassuming liquor store (with an awesome selection of 40'z btw), would have the best, if not THE ONLY...... Korean steak sandwich in the world. Take that LA! 

I knew I needed to come here after reading yelp friend Lolia S's review. She seriously puts in foodie work and she's right about the Korean steak sandwich being a masterpiece. 

Sweet, savory, spicy, crazy, sexy, cool.....  The Korean steak sandwich completely creates an addictive taste and flavor sensation. 

Marinated steak (honey, soy sauce, spices), garlic aioli, hot sauce + pickled jalapeno, with three types of onions, on a warmed acme roll, coughing, sneezing, so you can sleep medicine! This sandwich IS the Nyquil that puts my man food appetite to rest. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/humRe1SGupNdDJUxEdDmMg?select=8OX0OsarCVwtHx0H2M3pXw)

I'm going in for Rhea-tox next week.

excerpts: I've had the Korean Steak and Chicken Katsu on separate occasions.
Wait wasn't too long either times I went, but that was during off peak hours.
Parking nearby can take awhile
so I factor that into whether or not it's worth it to come.
Overall, pretty tasty for both sandwiches.
A bit pricier than I prefer and eating it can get messy as they are huge.
korean steak.author: Rick T.
korean steak.review: I've had the Korean Steak and Chicken Katsu on separate occasions. Wait wasn't too long either times I went, but that was during off peak hours. Parking nearby can take awhile so I factor that into whether or not it's worth it to come. Overall, pretty tasty for both sandwiches. excerpts: they have, in my most humblest of opinions, the city's best sandwich the Korean Steak Sandwich.

Maybe it's because I've been craving bulgogi lately, but man, when I took my first bite, it was like an angel was playing Canon in D Major on a harp in the background, and another angel on the Alto Sax, and of course another angel playing a TAMA Starclassic drumset.
korean steak.author: Ray R.
korean steak.review:
My work team and I have been on the hunt for SF's best sandwich.  Every week now it seems, we've hit up at least 2 new places hoping to hit the goldmine inbetwixt two slices of bread.  yes, i said inbetwixt.

Rhea's is a non-assuming deli on Valencia aka what I call SF's Gourmet Ghetto. It's a small place, nothing that sets it apart from the city's other 936,000 deli's except...they have, in my most humblest of opinions, the city's best sandwich the Korean Steak Sandwich.  Maybe it's because I've been craving bulgogi lately, but man, when I took my first bite, it was like an angel was playing Canon in D Major on a harp in the background, and another angel on the Alto Sax, and of course another angel playing a TAMA Starclassic drumset.  It was seriously like heaven.

Acme sweet roll - chewy on the outside, soft on the inside
Ribeye, sliced thin - it's Ribeye people! come on!
topped off with chili garlic sauce and a whole mess of onions
cheese - i chose swiss
and some lettuce for crunch.

It was a bit pricey and the sandwich, imo, was a bit small for the price, but you won't find a more flavorful sandwich in SF

I'm telling you son, git you some!

excerpts: The Korean steak sandwich was very tasty.
I got it "medium," which was PLENTY spicy.
korean steak.author: Chris C.
korean steak.review:
Saw this place on "Check Please."   It almost lived up to the hype.  The Korean steak sandwich was very tasty.  I got it "medium," which was PLENTY spicy. ( I have no idea why anyone would bother with the "spicy" option because I doubt you could taste the food with your mouth on fire.)

  The Katsu sandwich was much less impressive, and I won't order it again.  It could have been shoe leather in there, and I wouldn't really have noticed.  Not that it would have been bad though.

    The gimmick or the "hook" with these sandwiches is the excellent bread (Acme), (which is half the battle when it comes to sandwiches), and then the variety of ingredients/condiments added.  So every bite is a bit different and never boring.  When they add chili sauce, garlic aioli, jalapenos, pickled red onions, and a variety of veggies, it would be hard NOT to make something interesting.  So even though the "spicy goo" covers up some of the flavors, I'd be a regular if I lived in the area.

      I also got the regular kimchi, and it was one of the better ones I've tasted.  Nothing to rave about, just solid.

    As far as the place, it's a divey, liquor store.  Oh, and parking is friggin' ridiculous, as I circled for about 10 minutes to find a place about 4 blocks away.  Now I know why people park illegally...to save their sanity.

excerpts: Went with the Harrison St (Pastrami, cheese, peppers, chipotle aioli) and Korean Steak Sandwich (marinated steak, cheese, chili garlic sauce, pickled onions and grilled onions).
I originally wanted to eat half of both and leave the rest for later...
but no...
korean steak.author: Zoran L.
korean steak.review:
First things first... they serve Boars Head deli meats.  Always the best option if you get your meats from a grocery store and always the worst if you get them from an Italian deli or butcher.  Rhea's Market isn't italian nor a butcher... with that out of the way...

Now THAT'S how you serve Boars Head Deli Meats!!

I walked in and order right away...turns out there's usually a wait.  So I got lucky with my timing, however I struggled with trying to decide what to order... there are some really good sandwiches on the menu.  I decided to get two completely different flavors. Went with the Harrison St (Pastrami, cheese, peppers, chipotle aioli) and Korean Steak Sandwich (marinated steak, cheese, chili garlic sauce, pickled onions and grilled onions).  I originally wanted to eat half of both and leave the rest for later...but no...didn't happen...devoured both in one sitting.

Now have to be back for dinner...and lunch again tomorrow.  I'll be thinking about what to get all night... this menu requires planning.

And to the folks here from Chicago...they have REAL giardiniera...IN OIL.  Not the healthy west coast crap (in water) we have to put up with.  I'm so happy...

Fantastic sandwiches and everyone there is really friendly.  Can't wait to be back.

excerpts: Like everyone else in the world, I ordered The Korean Steak Sandwich (9.95), which was pretty damn tasty, and kind of problematic.
They certainly didn't skimp on delicious, ginger and soy marinated steak, and the well toasted, gloriously crunchy ciabatta roll did no harm.

The pickled onions and jalapenos perhaps too acidic, the cheese unmelted, but when taken together with a potent spice which skittered along my tongue like Saint Elmo's fire over the mast of a ship, and a rich garlic mayo, I can totally understandable how Rhea's could get away with charging ten dollars for this sandwich.
Its the sort of combination which hits every human need for spice, acidity, protein, fats, and carbs in just the right way, and leaves you craving for more.
korean steak.author: Casey U.
korean steak.review:
You know those nights when its cold, the bars are packed with people who you wouldn't want to have a drink around even if you were paid for it, you're tired, hungry, and early for an appointment? I had one of those last Friday, and walking down Valencia Street, seeing bar after bar filled with "Woo" people, and not in the financial straits to go for a sit down dinner, I decided on Rhea's, a longstanding fixture in the Mission and on my "bookmarks" list.

Like everyone else in the world, I ordered The Korean Steak Sandwich (9.95), which was pretty damn tasty, and kind of problematic. They certainly didn't skimp on delicious, ginger and soy marinated steak, and the well toasted, gloriously crunchy ciabatta roll did no harm. The pickled onions and jalapenos perhaps too acidic, the cheese unmelted, but when taken together with a potent spice which skittered along my tongue like Saint Elmo's fire over the mast of a ship, and a rich garlic mayo, I can totally understandable how Rhea's could get away with charging ten dollars for this sandwich. Its the sort of combination which hits every human need for spice, acidity, protein, fats, and carbs in just the right way, and leaves you craving for more. I can't give it five stars, but it comes pretty damn close. 

With sandwich in hand, I grabbed a bomber of Lagunitas from their cabinet (in a classy-as-fuck-paper bag), went out on the street, and inhaled my meal in a parklet while the endless parade of hip, tech folk walked past. At that moment, I was far happier outside on a cold night then I would have been in one of the crowded bars with fogged windows on every corner.

Overall: Four Stars. A somewhat problematic, but praiseworthy sandwich.

Extras:

Beers are a bit overpriced (by about a dollar)

Accessible to all Mission corridor bus lines, BART, the 33-Stanyan and 22-Fillmore.

excerpts: Korean steak sandwich
blah blah blah with a pork katsu thrown in every once in a while.
Once you've read one review for Rhea's, you've read them all.
korean steak.author: Kate V.
korean steak.review:
Yeah yeah yeah Korean steak sandwich blah blah blah with a pork katsu thrown in every once in a while. Once you've read one review for Rhea's, you've read them all. I don't need to tell you how AMAZEBALLS the aforementioned are since everyone else does a pretty good job with it, but I can say that it is definitely worth trying the other sandwiches and that I highly encourage other Yelpers to talk about them to give more balanced and helpful reviews.

For instance: I am currently indulging in a delicious Gargamel sandwich filled with (quoting from their menu) "grilled sweet soy and garlic-marinated chicken with housemade jicama slaw in vinaigrette, garlic aioli on toasted rosemary ciabatta." Now doesn't that sound YUMMY? Well it is!!! The jicama slaw has carrots in it and reminds me of the pickled veggies they put in banh mi. There's also some kind of lettuce that I think is baby romaine. And the chicken is excellent and different.

There ya go! Try something new at Rhea's.

Also, some quick updates as of 1/5/12 at 2:13pm PST:

*They're NOT selling either the pork or chicken katsu for an indefinite amount of time it seems, so don't even try. Yeah, I was pretty bummed too. 

*They used to do a jar deposit with their nomilicious kim chee, but they apparently don't anymore. So basically I wasted two extra bucks the first time I bought kim chee here and didn't need to bring back the empty jar today. I think it costs $6.99 now.

*They still are always crowded and only getting crowded-er, so do yourself a favor and call ahead. They also run out of sandwiches frequently, so get your butt up early to dial in your sando!

excerpts: I chose the korean steak sandwich and it was just the right combination of juicy steak, spicy sauce and sweet roll.
The line can get pretty long during lunch-time, but they take their time crafting each sandwich to perfection.
Make sure to eat it as soon as possible since the juiciness of the steak does tend to soak the bread after awhile.
korean steak.author: Dennis R.
korean steak.review:
I am now officially a believer. Rhea's makes one of the most delicious sandwiches I have ever had! I chose the korean steak sandwich and it was just the right combination of juicy steak, spicy sauce and sweet roll. The line can get pretty long during lunch-time, but they take their time crafting each sandwich to perfection. Make sure to eat it as soon as possible since the juiciness of the steak does tend to soak the bread after awhile.

Pro-tip: Walk a few blocks and enjoy a summer afternoon in Dolores with your sandwich!

excerpts: Their Korean Steak Sandwich is an all-time favorite and certainly deserves to be!
The Marinated Rib-Eye soaked in soy sauce, garlic, honey & spices will work wonders on your taste buds.
The pairing of the cheddar cheese is odd at first but gives an interesting texture in the end.
The pickled red onions, jalapeños, garlic aioli and shredded iceberg lettuce all compliment the Rib-Eye.
I really like
the Acme Organic bread roll
it's served on because it's the bread's texture and fluff
if just right.
A soft inside with a doughy, semi-crunch.
korean steak.author: Andrew C.
korean steak.review:
A hidden gem on Valencia, this has become one of my favorite spots for sandwiches. Looking like just another corner liquor store, Rhea's Deli & Market is home to some of the most delicious sandwiches the Mission has to offer.

Their Korean Steak Sandwich is an all-time favorite and certainly deserves to be! The Marinated Rib-Eye soaked in soy sauce, garlic, honey & spices will work wonders on your taste buds. The pairing of the cheddar cheese is odd at first but gives an interesting texture in the end. The pickled red onions, jalapeños, garlic aioli and shredded iceberg lettuce all compliment the Rib-Eye. I really like the Acme Organic bread roll it's served on because it's the bread's texture and fluff if just right. A soft inside with a doughy, semi-crunch. I order mine spicy because I enjoy the hotness.

Other sandwiches I've enjoyed here are the 18th St. (Hot Buffalo chicken, muenster cheese, bacon) and the Lexington (Honey Maple & Black Ham, swiss cheese, pickled jalapeños).

Most of their sandwiches have the garlic aioli sauce. You can also mix and match the bread rolls (Sweet, Herb, Dutch Crunch, Ciabatta).

A winning sandwich haven that also has a bunch of beers, sodas, juices and liquors to choose from. An ultimate hipster spot, this Deli Market is simply AWESOME.

excerpts: My recent favorite is the Korean steak sandwich with kimchi.
Limited bar seating in the back of the market.
Call ahead during lunch time to avoid the wait.
korean steak.author: Dinesh P.
korean steak.review: Market style deli with great sandwiches.  They make their own pastrami which is great.  My recent favorite is the Korean steak sandwich with kimchi.  Limited bar seating in the back of the market.  Call ahead during lunch time to avoid the wait.

excerpts: That dang Korean steak sandwich on dutch crunch with kimchi, spicy mayo, pickled red onions, lettuce and melted cheddar cheese...
korean steak.author: K M.
korean steak.review:
Damn, Rhea. Girl, you make a fine sandwich. 

That dang Korean steak sandwich on dutch crunch with kimchi, spicy mayo, pickled red onions, lettuce and melted cheddar cheese... I'm pretty sure if you saw me devouring it in Dolores that you would have thought I hadn't ate in years.

My sandwich + kombucha were $15, which is a price within the realm of reason. I paid with cash because their machines were down, so have some on you just in case. They said it'd take 15 mins to come out, but it took 10. That's it-- take your fine ass sandwich to the park. 

Just look at this beautiful thang http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=VCYtRcED5pBCZBwhEUI8Nw

excerpts: The Korean Steak Sandwich does not disappoint.
It's packed with flavor and has a nice spicy kick to it.
I went mild and it was more than enough spiciness for me.
But if you like hotness, you can definitely up it to medium or HOT.
I don't know what it was, but the spiciness lingered well after I finished my sandwich.
It only went away after I got my hands on a stick of gum.
The organic Acme roll is good.
The pickled red onions, lettuce, and grilled onions are all delish.
I didn't specify a cheese and I guess the default is cheddar because that's what I got.
It wasn't bad.
There was a definite contrast in the texture of the cheese versus the tenderness of the meat, but it wasn't a deal breaker.
I think next time, if available, I'd opt for some melted provolone instead.
I am really curious now to see how some gooey melted provolone would taste with the Korean steak.
Ahh, fuggit.
One more lunch hour won't hurt.
Thank you Yelp, for another great find.

Thank you Yelp, for another great find.
korean steak.author: Joe M.
korean steak.review:
A solid 4 stars.  The Korean Steak Sandwich does not disappoint.  It's packed with flavor and has a nice spicy kick to it.  I went mild and it was more than enough spiciness for me.  But if you like hotness, you can definitely up it to medium or HOT.  I don't know what it was, but the spiciness lingered well after I finished my sandwich.  It only went away after I got my hands on a stick of gum.  The organic Acme roll is good.  The pickled red onions, lettuce, and grilled onions are all delish.  I didn't specify a cheese and I guess the default is cheddar because that's what I got.  It wasn't bad.  There was a definite contrast in the texture of the cheese versus the tenderness of the meat, but it wasn't a deal breaker.  I think next time, if available, I'd opt for some melted provolone instead.  Oooh, now that sounds good!

The drive here from Mission Bay wasn't far, but definitely time-consuming.  I hate spending half my lunch hour driving so I'm not sure I'd come back on a work day.  I did score parking right in front, though.  (Thanks again, parking karma.)  I am really curious now to see how some gooey melted provolone would taste with the Korean steak.  Ahh, fuggit.  One more lunch hour won't hurt.  Thank you Yelp, for another great find.

excerpts: The Korean steak sandwich is worth the drive and totally worth the calories!
korean steak.author: Seisha L.
korean steak.review:
The Korean steak sandwich is worth the drive and totally worth the calories!

Rhea's is known for this sandwich for a good reason. It is overflowing with meat and dripping with flavor.

I'll admit that the sandwiches were good, but they aren't the best I've had.
The Korean Steak Sandwich tasted exactly how I expected to.
Imagine bulgogi in sandwich bread.
I personally don't think this combination goes well and found it very messy.
The Korean Steak Sandwich tasted exactly how I expected to.
Imagine bulgogi in sandwich bread.

The Valencia Street Sandwich was good, but the bread was a bit tough (the Korean Steak Sandwich's bread wasn't tough after being soaked by meat juices).

The sandwiches are large, but pricey, and don't come with a bag of chips.

korean steak.review: Decided to give Rhea's Deli a try because a friend said he likes it better than Ike's. We picked up a Korean Steak Sandwich and Valencia Street and headed over to Dolores park to enjoy our food. I'll admit that the sandwiches were good, but they aren't the best I've had. The Korean Steak Sandwich tasted exactly how I expected to. Imagine bulgogi in sandwich bread. I personally don't think this combination goes well and found it very messy. The Valencia Street Sandwich was good, but the bread was a bit tough (the Korean Steak Sandwich's bread wasn't tough after being soaked by meat juices).
